metadata.title: The omicron (B.1.1.529) SARS-CoV-2 variant of concern does not readily infect Syrian hamsters

abstract.text: 22 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 34 35 Keywords 36 COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2 VoC; Omicron; hamsters; infectivity 37 38 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f The establishment of an efficient preclinical infection model for emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants is 132 pivotal to assess the in vivo efficacy of therapeutic and prophylactic interventions (small molecule 133 antivirals and monoclonal antibodies) against these variants. However, because of the limited 134 infectivity of the omicron variant in two well-established SARS-CoV-2 animals models (i.e. in Syrian 135 hamsters and K18-hACE2 mice), this will not be possible for omicron. Given however that drugs and 136 antibodies should ideally be broadly active against any SARS-CoV-2 variant; this should not per se be 137 problematic. Indeed, the efficacy of such therapies will first need to be assessed in vitro whereby only 138 therapeutics with equipotent activity should be further considered. In such case, assessment of 139 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Conflict of Interest 160 None to declare 161 162 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern (VoCs) has exacerbated the COVID-19 pandemic. 24

End of November 2021, a new SARS-CoV-2 variant namely the omicron (B.1.1.529) emerged. Since this 25 omicron variant is heavily mutated in the spike protein, WHO classified this variant as the 5th variant 26 of concern (VoC). We previously demonstrated that the ancestral strain and the other SARS-CoV-2 27

VoCs replicate efficiently in and cause a COVID19-like pathology in Syrian hamsters. We here wanted 28 to explore the infectivity of the omicron variant in comparison to the ancestral D614G strain in the 29 hamster model. Strikingly, in hamsters that had been infected with the omicron variant, a 3 log10 lower 30 viral RNA load was detected in the lungs as compared to animals infected with D614G and no infectious 31 virus was detectable in this organ. Moreover, histopathological examination of the lungs from 32 omicron-infected hamsters revealed no signs of peri-bronchial inflammation or bronchopneumonia. 33

Variants of SARS-CoV-2 are still emerging in different parts of the world, posing a new public health 40 threat. Even in highly endemic regions, some of these variants have replaced the formerly dominant 41 strains and resulted in new waves of infections and new spikes in mortality (Plante et al., 2021) . On 24 42

November 2021, South Africa officially reported the emergence of B.1.1.529 (omicron) variant to WHO. 43 Two days later, the omicron variant has been classified by WHO as the 5th variant of concern (VoC) 44 following the alpha, beta, gamma and delta VoCs ("World Health Organization. Classification of 45 Omicron (B.1.1.529): SARS-CoV-2 Variant of Concern. 26/11/2021 (2021)," n.d.). Among these VoC, the 46 omicron variant carries the highest number of spike protein mutations (>30 mutations) (Karim and 47 tissue culture infectious doses (TCID50) of these stocks were determined by end-point titration on Vero 65 E6 as described before (Boudewijns et al., 2020; Kaptein et al., 2020) . The calculated TCID50/mL values 66 for the ancestral D614G strain and the omicron variant were 7.07x10 5 and 1.6x10 6 , respectively. The 67 hamster infection model of SARS-CoV-2 has been described before (Boudewijns et al., 2020; Kaptein 68 et al., 2020) . In Brief, 6-8 weeks old female Syrian hamsters were intranasally infected with 50 µL 69 containing approximately 10 3 TCID50 of either the ancestral strain (BavPat(D614G)) or the omicron VoC 70 (B.1.1.529) SARS-CoV-2 ( Fig. 1a) . At day four post-infection (4 dpi), animals were euthanized for 71 sampling of the lungs and further analysis by i.p. injection of 500 μL Dolethal (200 mg/mL sodium 72 pentobarbital) (Abdelnabi et al., 2021a) . Housing conditions and experimental procedures were 73 approved by the ethics committee of animal experimentation of KU Leuven (license P065-2020). 74

A median viral RNA load of 4x10 6 RNA copies/mg of lung tissue was detected at 4 dpi in the lungs from 75 the animals infected with the D614G strain (Fig. 1b) . On the other hand, ~3 log10 lower viral RNA loads 76 (possibly input only) were detected in the lungs of animals infected with the omicron variant (a median 77 vira RNA load of 3x10 3 RNA copies/mg lung tissue, p=0.0022, Mann-Whitney Test), Fig. 1b . Infectious 78 virus titers in the lungs of D614G strain-infected animals were around 2x10 4 TCID50/mg of lung tissue 79 ( Fig. 1c) . Strikingly, no infectious virus was detected at all in the lungs of all animals infected with the 80 omicron variant (Fig. 1c , P=0022 compared to the D614G strain-infected group, Mann-Whitney Test). 81 This is also very different from the other four VoCs that all replicate efficiently and consistently to 82 high viral loads in Syrian hamster lungs (Abdelnabi et al., 2021a (Abdelnabi et al., , 2021b Sharma et al., 2021) . On the 83 day of sacrifice, animals infected with the omicron variant had gained more body weight (average 84 body weight change from d0 of 3.8%) than the D614G strain-infected animals (average body weight 85 change from d0 of 0.65%), p=.0087, Mann-Whitney Test (Fig. 1d) . 86

For histological examination, the lungs were fixed overnight in 4% formaldehyde and embedded in 87 paraffin. Tissue sections were analyzed after staining with hematoxylin and eosin and scored blindly 88 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f for lung damage by an expert pathologist. The scored parameters, to which a cumulative score of 1 to 89 3 was attributed, were the following: congestion, intra-alveolar hemorrhagic, apoptotic bodies in 90 bronchus wall, necrotizing bronchiolitis, perivascular edema, bronchopneumonia, perivascular 91 inflammation, peribronchial inflammation and vasculitis.Hematoxylin/eosin (H&E)-stained images of 92 lungs of hamsters infected with the D614G strain revealed significant pathological signs including peri-93 bronchial inflammation, bronchopneumonia in the surrounding alveoli and perivascular inflammation 94 with peri-vascular oedema (Fig. 2a) . The median cumulative histopathological lung score of the D614G-95 infected hamsters was 7.5 ( Fig. 2b) , which is comparable to what we previously reported for this strain 96 (Abdelnabi et al., 2021a) . Unlike the D614G strain-infected group, no inflammation or disease signs 97 were observed in the lungs of the omicron-infected animals on day 4 pi (Fig. 2a) . The median 98 cumulative histopathological lung scores of the omicron-infected animals was close to the baseline 99 score in untreated, non-infected hamsters (median score of 1.75, Fig. 2b , P=0022 compared to the 100 D614G group, Mann-Whitney Test). 101

Taken together, these results clearly demonstrate that the omicron is not able to efficiently replicate 102 in the lower respiratory tract of Syrian hamsters compared to the ancestral D614G strain and other 103 variants of concerns. Similarly, other research groups reported that the viral loads and pathology signs 104 in the lungs of omicron-infected hamsters were much lower compared to the basal strains and the 105 other VoCs (Diamond et al., 2021; McMahan et al., 2022) . One possible explanation may be that the 106 heavily mutated spike of the omicron variant is so much better adapted to the human ACE2 receptor 107 hence making the attachment of this variant to the hamster ACE2 less efficient. Interestingly a recent 108 study using human ACE2 transgenic mice (i.e. K18-hACE2 mouse model) revealed that omicron 109

replicates also much less efficiently in nasal tissues and lungs and causes much less severe signs of 110 disease as compared to mice infected with either the ancestral strain or the delta variant (Bentley et 111 al., 2021) . In another study, omicron-infected human ACE2 transgenic hamsters also showed reduced 112 mortality and infectious virus loads in the lung compared to those infected with the D614G strain 113 (Diamond et al., 2021) . Thus a better adaptation to human ACE2 cannot explain the limited infectivity shifted to the upper respiratory tract resulting in limited lung infectivity and hence less also less severe 116 disease. This would be in line with the recently reported data in ex-vivo models from which it is evident 117 that the omicron variant is 70-fold more efficient in replicating in human bronchus tissues than the 118 delta variant but much less efficiently replicating in human lung tissues (Chi-wai, 2021). The cellular 119 entry of the ancestral strains and that of the non-omicron VoCs depend on binding of the S1 subunit 120 of the Spike (S) protein to the ACE2 receptor (Hoffmann et al., 2020) . This process is accompanied by 121 S-protein cleavage (activation) by the transmembrane serine protease 2 (TMPRSS2) to allow the fusion 122 of viral and cellular membranes (Hoffmann et al., 2020) . However, recent studies showed that the 123 omicron variant replicates much less efficiently in TMPRSS2-overexpressing cell lines as compared to 124 the delta variant (Meng et al., 2021; Peacock et al., 2022; Zhao et al., 2021) Abdelnabi, R., Boudewijns, R., Foo, C.S., Seldeslachts, L., Sanchez-Felipe, L., Zhang, X., Delang, L., 164 Maes, P., Kaptein, S.J.F., Weynand, B., Vande Velde, G., Neyts, J., Dallmeier, K., 2021a. 165 Comparing infectivity and virulence of emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants in Syrian hamsters. 166

FIGREF0.text: . Moreover, unlike the 125 ancestral strains and other VoCs, omicron enters cells more efficiently via the endocytic cathepsin L 126 pathway (Peacock et al., 2022; Zhao et al., 2021). These findings could explain the ability of the omicron 127 variant to replicate better than other variants in the cells of the upper respiratory tract that lack the 128 TMPRSS2 expression. Therefore, further experiments are required to assess the viral loads in lung and 129 other tissues from the upper respiratory tract of omicron-infected hamster at different time points 130 post-infection to explain the limited lung infectivity observed in this study. 131 efficacy in animal infection models could be performed using any of the other VoC as a Hendricks for excellent technical assistance with animal experimentation and molecular 145 sample analysis. (a) Set-up of the Syrian hamster infection study. (b) Viral RNA levels in the 259 lungs of hamsters infected with 10 3 TCID50 of BavPat (D614G) strain (n=6) or the omicron (B.1.1.529) 260 SARS-CoV-2 variant (n=6) on day 4 post-infection (pi) are expressed as log10 SARS-CoV-2 RNA copies 261 per mg lung tissue. Individual data and median values are presented. (c) Infectious viral loads in the 262 lungs of hamsters infected with the D614G strain or the omicron variant at day 4 pi are expressed as 263 log10 TCID50 per mg lung tissue. Individual data and median values are presented. (d) Weight change at 264 day 4 pi in percentage, normalized to the body weight at the time of infection. Bars represent means 265 ± SD. Data were analyzed with the Mann−Whitney U test, **P < 0.01. All data are from a single 266 experiment. Histopathology of lungs of Syrian hamsters infected with either the D614G strain or the 268 omicron SARS-CoV-2 variant. (a) Representative H&E images of lungs of hamsters infected with 10 3 269 TCID50 of BavPat (D614G) strain (n=6) or the omicron (B.1.1.529) SARS-CoV-2 variant at day 4 post-270 infection (pi). The lungs of hamsters infected with the ancestral D614G strain (left picture) show 271 significant bronchopneumonia (green arrows), perivascular inflammation with peri-vascular oedema 272 (red arrows) and peri-bronchial inflammation (blue arrows), whereas the lungs of the omicron-infected 273 hamsters (Right picture) appear normal with no peri-bronchial inflammation (blue arrows) or 274 bronchopneumonia. Scale bars, 100 μm. (b) Cumulative severity score from H&E stained slides of lungs 275 from hamsters infected with the D614G strain or the omicron variant at day 4 pi. Individual data and 276 median values are presented and the dotted line represents the median score of untreated non-277
